title-group.article-title: Primary Squamous Cell Carcinoma of Breast: A Short Report and Immunohistochemical Review

article-meta.aff: Department of Pathology, Dr. D. Y. Patil Medical College, Hospital and Research Centre, Dr. D. Y. Patil Vidyapeeth, Pune, Maharashtra, India

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Primary squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the breast is classified by the World Health Organization as a metaplastic carcinoma, meaning that it is made up solely of squamous cells that have undergone metaplasia and frequently show variable degrees of keratinization. Less than 0.1% of all invasive breast carcinomas are primary SCCs, making them incredibly uncommon. The exact cause and development of SCC in the breast remain uncertain. Some suggest it could represent an extreme form of squamous cell metaplasia progressing into adenocarcinoma, potentially explaining its mixed forms. Existing literature reveals only a handful of documented cases to date. This malignancy is notably aggressive, typically lacking hormone receptor expression (triple negative), resistant to standard treatments, and associated with a bad prognosis.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) predominantly occurs in tissues lined with squamous cells, such as the skin, esophagus, and anus. Less than 0.1% of all invasive breast carcinomas are primary SCCs, making them incredibly uncommon in the context of breast cancer.[1] Primary SCC of the breast is defined by the World Health Organization as a metaplastic carcinoma (MC) made up only of squamous cells that have undergone metaplasia and frequently show variable degrees of keratinization.[2] The differentiation of neoplastic epithelial cells into squamous or mesenchymal cell types, including osseous, chondroid, and spindle segments, characterises the MC subtype of invasive breast cancers.[3] Existing literature reveals only a handful of documented cases to date. This malignancy is notably aggressive, typically lacking hormone receptor expression (triple negative), resistant to standard treatments, and associated with a bleak prognosis.[4]

sec.title: CASE REPORT
sec.p: A 49-year-old postmenopausal woman presented with a lump in her right breast of 2 months duration, characterized by insidious onset and gradual progression. The lump was associated with purulent and foul-smelling discharge. Mild bleeding from the nipple was present, which was not associated with pain and fever. Physical examination revealed bilateral breasts at the same level, with no abnormalities detected in the left breast. The right breast exhibited a nontender lump measuring 4 cm × 5 cm in the upper outer quadrant behind the nipple-areolar complex. The lump was associated with excoriation of the skin and nipple retraction. The skin over the swelling was adhered to, and no active bleeding was observed. Palpation of the right axilla revealed palpable lymphadenopathy.

Ultrasound examination of both breasts indicated an abscess in the right breast with concurrent right axillary lymphadenopathy. The left breast exhibited a small, well-defined oval cyst, suggesting a benign lesion. Magnetic resonance imaging of the breasts revealed a large ulcerative, irregular heterogeneous mass diffusely involving the right breast with irregular margins and heterogeneous enhancement, consistent with breast cancer (American collage of radiology, breast imaging reporting and data system). The left breast showed a well-defined oval cyst suggestive of a benign lesion (ACR BIRADS 2). Positron emission tomography computed tomography scan demonstrated a hypermetabolic mass lesion predominantly involving the right breast outer quadrant, indicative of primary malignancy.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the right breast lump and axillary lymph node confirmed malignancy in the right breast with metastasis to the axillary lymph node. Histopathological examination (HPE) of the TRUCUT biopsy from the right breast lump revealed ductal adenocarcinoma of the breast with focal areas of squamous differentiation. Subsequently, due to the confirmed malignancy on histopathology, the patient underwent a total mastectomy and was sent for further HPE. We received the excised specimen of the right breast following the toilet mastectomy. On gross examination, the tumor measured 6.5 cm × 6 cm × 4.5 cm, and on cut sections, the tumor was gray-white with solid areas [Figure 1a and b]. Microscopy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma with an extensive squamous component with the pathologic stage pT3 pN1a [Figure 1c and d]. All the margins were free of tumor. The skin overlying the breast was also normal histologically. Immunohistochemistry done on this specimen to rule out primary SCC from MC revealed estrogen receptor – negative, progesterone receptor – negative, human epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) 2 – negative, Cytokeratin 7 – positive, Ki67 – >20% high grade, P63-positive and GATA binding protein 3-negative confirming it as primary SCC [Figure 2a-d].

caption.p: (a) Figure of the right breast (anterior surface), showing a large fungating retro-areolar tumor eroding skin, (b) Figure showing inked posterior surface with tumor and grossly free base, (c) Photomicrograph showing entire tumor with squamous differentiation (H and E, ×200), (d) Photomicrograph showing Malignant Squamous cells in sheets (H and E, ×400)
Figure showing Immunohistochemistry sections with (a) showing cytokeratin 7 Positivity, (b) P-63 Positivity, (c) Ki-67 high grade, (d) GATA-3 negative. CK-7: Cytokeratin 7

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: According to Macia et al.’s[5] diagnostic criteria, pure SCC of the breast has been documented in about 50 reports and two significant series. These include 33 cases from MD Anderson Cancer Centre and eleven cases reported by a Spanish research group.[6]
Macia et al.[5] defined pure SCC as a type of tumor that:

list-item.p: Contains only SCC cells, without any other types of cancerous tissue such as ductal or mesenchymal elements
It develops independently from the skin and nipple tissues that overlay it and does not have an associated primary SCC in another location

According to Rosen,[7] SCC of the breast diagnosis necessitates the presence of in situ squamous carcinoma within the ducts. They define SCC as a lesion with more than 90% of the tumor comprising squamous carcinoma or its variants. In the case described here, the tumor exhibited an intraductal component, with over 90% of the malignant cells being squamous in nature. They also noted that cystic degeneration accompanies primary SCC rather than metastatic SCC.

sec.p: The exact cause and development of SCC in the breast remain uncertain. Some suggest it could represent an extreme form of squamous cell metaplasia progressing into adenocarcinoma, potentially explaining its mixed forms.[8] Squamous cell metaplasia is commonly observed in cysts, chronic inflammations, abscesses, and adenofibromas, but in this particular case, no such preexisting abnormalities were noted. SCC of the breast typically presents with inflammation and tends to grow larger than adenocarcinomas. It predominantly affects elderly individuals, often resulting in large tumors up to 5 cm in size.

Mammograms usually do not reveal distinctive features, while ultrasound may show a complex cyst or signs of inflammation. HPE of SCC typically reveals large malignant squamoid cells arranged in sheets with intercellular bridges and keratin formation. Unlike adenocarcinomas, SCCs are reported to have less lymphatic spread initially, but lymph node involvement may still occur in 10%–30% of cases at the time of surgery.[8] Approximately 30% of patients may develop distant metastases. Treatment strategies for SCC of the breast generally mirror those for other common types of breast cancer, including surgery, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, and radiation. However, due to its rarity, the optimal therapeutic approach remains to be determined. According to recent research, over 70% of individuals with breast SCC do not initially exhibit involvement of the axillary lymph nodes.

Nevertheless, axillary lymph node dissection is frequently performed for staging due to the unpredictability of lymph node spread.[9] Typically, chemotherapeutic drugs, including methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), and anthracyclines, which are frequently used for ductal carcinoma, do not work well against SCC.[10] In a few situations, 5-FU and cisplatin have demonstrated potential in treating metastatic illness; nevertheless, more research is required.

SCC of the breast is usually hormone receptor-negative and high-grade, making hormone-based therapies ineffective. HER2/neu expression is typically amplified in this disease, but there is often a high frequency of EGFR positivity, suggesting potential avenues for future treatment development. The prognosis of SCC remains somewhat controversial, with many studies indicating it behaves aggressively, similar to poorly differentiated breast carcinoma. A small retrospective series reported a 5-year survival rate of 67% among eleven patients.[9]

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: In summary, breast SCC is an exceptionally aggressive cancer, frequently resulting in both local and distant recurrences, which often lead to death. There is a pressing need for improved systemic therapies to enhance patient outcomes. Determining EGFR’s potential as a therapeutic target requires examining its function in this form of cancer and its associated signaling pathways. Clinical trials combining anti-EGFR therapies with synergistic cytotoxic drugs such as taxanes and platinum should be considered. Furthermore, it is imperative to conduct biological studies on these uncommon breast tumors to comprehend the reasons behind chemotherapy resistance and to find additional treatment targets.

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: The original contributions presented in the study are included in the article/supplementary material. Further inquiries can be directed to the corresponding author. Data will be made available by the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

sec.title: Ethical statement
sec.p: Consent of the patient was taken, and ethical clearance was approved by the institution.

sec.title: Declaration of patient consent
sec.p: The authors certify that they have obtained all appropriate patient consent forms. In the form, the patient has given her consent for her images and other clinical information to be reported in the journal. The patient understands that her name and initials will not be published and that due efforts will be made to conceal her identity, but anonymity cannot be guaranteed.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: There are no conflicts of interest.
